chunk:
The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Mitigation method description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Limit Software Installation
Mitigation method description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering.

entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks the execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: Network Intrusion Prevention is a mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: Network Segmentation is a mitigation method that involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems and prevent access to sensitive information.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method that trains users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by adversaries to reduce risks.

entities.name: RESTRICT REGISTRY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict Registry Permissions is a mitigation method that restricts the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that restricts access by setting directory and file permissions.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that makes configuration changes to harden the system against techniques.

entities.name: LIMIT ACCESS TO RESOURCE OVER NETWORK
entities.description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network is a mitigation method that prevents access to file shares and remote systems.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation and permissions associated with privileged accounts.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a mitigation method that removes or denies access to unnecessary software to prevent abuse.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that prevents suspicious behavior patterns on endpoint systems.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation and permissions associated with user accounts.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a mitigation method that protects sensitive information with strong encryption.

entities.description: Limit Software Installation is a mitigation method that blocks users from installing unapproved software.)<|COMPLETE|>("entity"

chunk:
The following content describes information about software. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: GravityRAT
Software description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) is a remote access tool (RAT) and has been in ongoing development since 2016. The actor behind the tool remains unknown, but two usernames have been recovered that link to the author, which are "TheMartian" and "The Invincible." According to the National Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) of India, the malware has been identified in attacks against organization and entities in India. (Citation: Talos GravityRAT)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Disco
Software description: [Disco](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1088) is a custom implant that has been used by [MoustachedBouncer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1019) since at least 2020 including in campaigns using targeted malicious content injection for initial access and command and control.(Citation: MoustachedBouncer ESET August 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POORAIM
Software description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) is a backdoor used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) in campaigns since at least 2014. (Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Shamoon
Software description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) is wiper malware that was first used by an Iranian group known as the "Cutting Sword of Justice" in 2012. Other versions known as Shamoon 2 and Shamoon 3 were observed in 2016 and 2018. [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has also been seen leveraging [RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364) and Filerase to carry out data wiping tasks. Analysis has linked [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) with [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) based on multiple shared artifacts and coding patterns.(Citation: Cylera Kwampirs 2022) The term Shamoon is sometimes used to refer to the group using the malware as well as the malware itself.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Tarrask
Software description: [Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) is malware that has been used by [HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) since at least August 2021. [Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) was designed to evade digital defenses and maintain persistence by generating concealed scheduled tasks.(Citation: Tarrask scheduled task)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NotPetya
Software description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) is malware that was used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) in a worldwide attack starting on June 27, 2017. While [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) appears as a form of ransomware, its main purpose was to destroy data and disk structures on compromised systems; the attackers never intended to make the encrypted data recoverable. As such, [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) may be more appropriately thought of as a form of wiper malware. [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) contains worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network using the SMBv1 exploits EternalBlue and EternalRomance.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)(Citation: ESET Telebots June 2017)(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Unit 74455 October 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Smoke Loader
Software description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) is a malicious bot application that can be used to load other malware.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) has been seen in the wild since at least 2011 and has included a number of different payloads. It is notorious for

entities.name: DISCO
entities.description: Disco is a custom implant used by MoustachedBouncer since at least 2020 for targeted malicious content injection.

entities.name: QAKBOT
entities.description: QakBot is a modular banking trojan used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007, evolving into a delivery agent for ransomware.

entities.name: POORAIM
entities.description: POORAIM is a backdoor used by APT37 in campaigns since at least 2014.

entities.name: SHAMOON
entities.description: Shamoon is wiper malware first used by an Iranian group known as the "Cutting Sword of Justice" in 2012, with multiple versions observed since.

entities.name: TARRASK
entities.description: Tarrask is malware used by HAFNIUM since at least August 2021, designed to evade digital defenses and maintain persistence.

entities.name: NOTPETYA
entities.description: NotPetya is malware used by Sandworm Team in a worldwide attack starting on June 27, 2017, primarily aimed at destroying data.

entities.name: SMOKE LOADER
entities.description: Smoke Loader is a malicious bot application that can load other malware, seen in the wild since at least 2011.

entities.name: MOUSTACHEDBOUNCER
entities.description: MoustachedBouncer is a group that has been using Disco since at least 2020 for targeted malicious content injection.

entities.name: APT37
entities.description: APT37 is a group that has been using POORAIM in their campaigns since at least 2014.

entities.name: CUTTING SWORD OF JUSTICE
entities.description: The Cutting Sword of Justice is an Iranian group known for using Shamoon malware.

entities.name: HAFNIUM
entities.description: HAFNIUM is a group that has been using Tarrask malware since at least August 2021.

entities.name: SANDWORM TEAM
entities.description: Sandworm Team is the group responsible for deploying NotPetya in a worldwide attack.

entities.name: THE INVINCIBLE
entities.description: The Invincible is another username associated with the author of GravityRAT, with the actual identity still undisclosed.

entities.name: PROLOCK
entities.description: ProLock is a type of ransomware that has been delivered using QakBot.

entities.name: EGREGOR
entities.description: Egregor is another type of ransomware that has been delivered using QakBot.

Platforms: Windows

Software name: Smoke Loader
Software description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) is a malicious bot application that can be used to load other malware.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) has been seen in the wild since at least 2011 and has included a number of different payloads. It is notorious for its use of deception and self-protection. It also comes with several plug-ins. (Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016) (Citation: Microsoft Dofoil 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Olympic Destroyer
Software description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) is malware that was used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) against the 2018 Winter Olympics, held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The main purpose of the malware was to render infected computer systems inoperable. The malware leverages various native Windows utilities and API calls to carry out its destructive tasks. [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) has worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network in order to maximize its destructive impact.(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer 2018)(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Unit 74455 October 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EKANS
Software description: [EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) is ransomware variant written in Golang that first appeared in mid-December 2019 and has been used against multiple sectors, including energy, healthcare, and automotive manufacturing, which in some cases resulted in significant operational disruptions. [EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) has used a hard-coded kill-list of processes, including some associated with common ICS software platforms (e.g., GE Proficy, Honeywell HMIWeb, etc), similar to those defined in [MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576).(Citation: Dragos EKANS)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 EKANS)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ProLock
Software description: [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) is a ransomware strain that has been used in Big Game Hunting (BGH) operations since at least 2020, often obtaining initial access with [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650). [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) is the successor to PwndLocker ransomware which was found to contain a bug allowing decryption without ransom payment in 2019.(Citation: Group IB Ransomware September 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Rclone
Software description: [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) is a command line program for syncing files with cloud storage services such as Dropbox, Google Drive, Amazon S3, and MEGA. [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) has been used in a number of ransomware campaigns, including those associated with the [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) and DarkSide Ransomware-as-a-Service operations.(Citation: Rclone)(Citation: Rclone Wars)(Citation: Detecting Rclone)(Citation: DarkSide Ransomware Gang)(Citation: DFIR Conti Bazar Nov 2021)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Software name: Cobalt Strike
Software description: [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as “adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors”. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)

In addition to its own capabilities, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: T9000
Software description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) is a backdoor that is a newer variant of the T5000 malware family, also known as Plat1. Its primary function is to gather information about the victim. It has been used in multiple targeted attacks against U.S.-based organizations. (Citation: FireEye admin@338 March 2014) (Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: JHUHUGIT
Software description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is malware used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BackConfig
Software description: [BackConfig](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0475)

Software name: BackConfig
Software description: [BackConfig](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0475) is a custom Trojan with a flexible plugin architecture that has been used by [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040).(Citation: Unit 42 BackConfig May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Lokibot
Software description: [Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) is a widely distributed information stealer that was first reported in 2015. It is designed to steal sensitive information such as usernames, passwords, cryptocurrency wallets, and other credentials. [Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) can also create a backdoor into infected systems to allow an attacker to install additional payloads.(Citation: Infoblox Lokibot January 2019)(Citation: Morphisec Lokibot April 2020)(Citation: CISA Lokibot September 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: XCSSET
Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(Citation: trendmicro xcsset xcode project 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Cyclops Blink
Software description: [Cyclops Blink](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0687) is a modular malware that has been used in widespread campaigns by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) since at least 2019 to target Small/Home Office (SOHO) network devices, including WatchGuard and Asus.(Citation: NCSC Cyclops Blink February 2022)(Citation: NCSC CISA Cyclops Blink Advisory February 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Cyclops Blink March 2022)
Platforms: Network

Software name: SQLRat
Software description: [SQLRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0390) is malware that executes SQL scripts to avoid leaving traditional host artifacts. [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has been observed using it.(Citation: Flashpoint FIN 7 March 2019)
Platforms: None

Software name: JSS Loader
Software description: [JSS Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0648) is Remote Access Trojan (RAT) with .NET and C++ variants that has been used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) since at least 2020.(Citation: eSentire FIN7 July 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike Carbon Spider August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PoetRAT
Software description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that was first identified in April 2020. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has been used in multiple campaigns against the private and public sectors in Azerbaijan, including ICS and SCADA systems in the energy sector. The STIBNITE activity group has been observed using the malware. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) derived its name from references in the code to poet William Shakespeare. (Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)(Citation: Talos PoetRAT October 2020)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FruitFly
Software description: FruitFly is designed to spy on mac users  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: POWERSTATS
Software description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) is a PowerShell-based first stage backdoor used by [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069). (Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PyDCrypt
Software description: [PyDCrypt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1032) is malware written in Python designed to deliver [DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033). It has been used by [Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) since at least September 2021, with each sample tailored for its intended victim organization.(Citation: Checkpoint MosesStaff Nov 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Impacket
Software description: [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols. [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) contains several tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.(Citation: Impacket Tools)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: RegDuke
Software description: [RegDuke](https

key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Trend Micro is a global cybersecurity leader that provides security software and threat intelligence services.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="CISA">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) is a U.S. government agency responsible for protecting the nation's critical infrastructure from cyber threats.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="FIN7">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">FIN7 is a cybercriminal group known for its sophisticated attacks and use of various malware, including SQLRat and JSS Loader.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="MUDDYWATER">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">MuddyWater is a cyber threat group known for its use of PowerShell-based malware and targeting various sectors.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="MOSES STAFF">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Moses Staff is a cyber threat group that has been observed using PyDCrypt malware in its operations.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="STIBNITE">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">STIBNITE is a cyber threat group that has been linked to the use of PoetRAT malware in attacks against various sectors.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="ALHAMIA PRISON">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">Alhamia Prison is a facility located in Tiruzia, Firuzabad, where hostages were held.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="WINDOWS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Windows is an operating system platform that supports various software applications, including malware.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="MACOS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">macOS is an operating system platform designed for Apple computers, which is targeted by specific malware like XCSSET and FruitFly.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="LINUX">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Linux is an open-source operating system that supports various software applications, including Impacket.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>    </node>    <node id="SQLRAT">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">SQLRat is malware that executes SQL scripts to avoid leaving traditional host artifacts and has been used by FIN7.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>      <data key="d3">EVENT</data>    </node>    <node id="JSS LOADER">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">JSS Loader is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) used by FIN7 since at least 2020.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>      <data key="d3">EVENT</data>    </node>    <node id="POWERSTATS">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">POWERSTATS is a PowerShell-based backdoor used by MuddyWater.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>      <data key="d3">EVENT</data>    </node>    <node id="PYDCRYPT">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">PyDCrypt is malware written in Python designed to deliver DCSrv and has been used by Moses Staff.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>      <data key="d3">EVENT</data>    </node>    <node id="BACKCONFIG"> access trojan that has been used in campaigns against various sectors in Azerbaijan.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>      <data key="d3">EVENT</data>    </node>    <node id="LOKIBOT">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">Lokibot is a widely distributed information stealer designed to steal sensitive information and create backdoors into infected systems.</data>      <data key="d2">40043e89f91c0bb3afac84419d0542e3</data>      <data key="d3">EVENT</data>    </node>    <node id="XCSSET">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data chunk:
https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols. [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) contains several tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.(Citation: Impacket Tools)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: RegDuke
Software description: [RegDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0511) is a first stage implant written in .NET and used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2017. [RegDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0511) has been used to control a compromised machine when control of other implants on the machine was lost.(Citation: ESET Dukes October 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Carbon
Software description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) is a sophisticated, second-stage backdoor and framework that can be used to steal sensitive information from victims. [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) has been selectively used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) to target government and foreign affairs-related organizations in Central Asia.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)(Citation: Securelist Turla Oct 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cannon
Software description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi. It was first observed in April 2018. (Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AppleSeed
Software description: [AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) is a backdoor that has been used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) to target South Korean government, academic, and commercial  targets since at least 2021.(Citation: Malwarebytes Kimsuky June 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: BlackEnergy
Software description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) is a malware toolkit that has been used by both criminal and APT actors. It dates back to at least 2007 and was originally designed to create botnets for use in conducting Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, but its use has evolved to support various plug-ins. It is well known for being used during the confrontation between Georgia and Russia in 2008, as well as in targeting Ukrainian institutions. Variants include BlackEnergy 2 and BlackEnergy 3. (Citation: F-Secure BlackEnergy 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DOGCALL
Software description: [DOGCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0213) is a backdoor used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) that has been used to target South Korean government and military organizations in 2017. It is typically dropped using a Hangul Word Processor (HWP) exploit. (Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TinyTurla
Software description: [TinyTurla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0668) is a backdoor that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) against targets in the US, Germany, and Afghanistan since at least 2020.(Citation: Talos TinyTurla September 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FinFisher
Software description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) is a government-grade commercial surveillance spyware reportedly sold exclusively to government agencies for use in targeted and lawful criminal investigations. It is heavily obfuscated and uses multiple anti-analysis techniques. It has other variants including [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176). (Citation: FinFisher Citation) (Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21) (Citation: FireEye FinSpy Sept 2017) (Citation: Securelist BlackOasis Oct 2017) (Citation: Microsoft FinFisher March 2018)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: Revenge RAT
Software description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ramsay
Software description: [Ramsay](https://

entities.name: IMPACKET
entities.description: Impacket is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols, containing tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.

entities.name: REGDUKE
entities.description: RegDuke is a first stage implant written in .NET and used by APT29 since at least 2017 to control compromised machines.

entities.name: EMPIRE
entities.description: Empire is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub, primarily written in Python with post-exploitation agents in PowerShell and Python.

entities.name: CARBON
entities.description: Carbon is a sophisticated, second-stage backdoor and framework used to steal sensitive information, selectively used by Turla to target government and foreign affairs-related organizations in Central Asia.

entities.name: CANNON
entities.description: Cannon is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi, first observed in April 2018.

entities.name: APPLESEED
entities.description: AppleSeed is a backdoor used by Kimsuky to target South Korean government, academic, and commercial targets since at least 2021.

entities.name: BLACKENERGY
entities.description: BlackEnergy is a malware toolkit used by both criminal and APT actors, originally designed for creating botnets for DDoS attacks, and known for its use during the confrontation between Georgia and Russia in 2008.

entities.name: DOGCALL
entities.description: DOGCALL is a backdoor used by APT37 to target South Korean government and military organizations, typically dropped using a Hangul Word Processor exploit.

entities.name: TINY TURLA
entities.description: TinyTurla is a backdoor used by Turla against targets in the US, Germany, and Afghanistan since at least 2020.

entities.name: FINFISHER
entities.description: FinFisher is a government-grade commercial surveillance spyware sold exclusively to government agencies for targeted investigations, heavily obfuscated with multiple anti-analysis techniques.

entities.name: REVENGE RAT
entities.description: Revenge RAT is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).

entities.name: GITHUB
entities.description: GitHub is a platform for version control and collaboration, where open source projects like Empire are hosted.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a sophisticated cyber espionage group known for using advanced malware like Carbon and TinyTurla to target government and military organizations.

entities.name: KIMSUKY
entities.description: Kimsuky is a North Korean cyber espionage group that targets South Korean government, academic, and commercial entities.

entities.name: GEORGIA
entities.description: Georgia is a country that was targeted during the cyber attacks associated with BlackEnergy in 2008.

entities.name: RUSSIA
entities.description: Russia is a country involved in the confrontation with Georgia, during which BlackEnergy was notably used.

entities.name: SOUTH KOREA
entities.description: South Korea is a country that has been targeted by various cyber espionage groups, including APT37 and Kimsuky.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that many of the mentioned malware and tools, such as RegDuke and BlackEnergy, are designed to operate on.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that supports various tools like Empire and Impacket.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that supports tools like Empire and Impacket.)<|COMPLETE|>

TURLA">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">TinyTurla is a backdoor used by Turla against targets in the US, Germany, and Afghanistan since at least 2020.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="FINFISHER">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">FinFisher is a government-grade commercial surveillance spyware sold exclusively to government agencies for targeted investigations, heavily obfuscated with multiple anti-analysis techniques.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="REVENGE RAT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Revenge RAT is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="APT29">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="GITHUB">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">GitHub is a platform for version control and collaboration, where open source projects like Empire are hosted.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>      <data key="d3">ORGANIZATION</data>    </node>    <node id="TURLA">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">Turla is a sophisticated cyber espionage group known for using advanced malware like Carbon and TinyTurla to target government and military organizations.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>      <data key="d3">ORGANIZATION</data>    </node>    <node id="KIMSUKY">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">Kimsuky is a North Korean cyber espionage group that targets South Korean government, academic, and commercial entities.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>      <data key="d3">ORGANIZATION</data>    </node>    <node id="GEORGIA">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">Georgia is a country that was targeted during the cyber attacks associated with BlackEnergy in 2008.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>      <data key="d3">GEO</data>    </node>    <node id="APT37">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="GOVERNMENT AGENCIES">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="OPEN SOURCE">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="RUSSIA">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">Russia is a country involved in the confrontation with Georgia, during which BlackEnergy was notably used.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="SOUTH KOREA">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">South Korea is a country that has been targeted by various cyber espionage groups, including APT37 and Kimsuky.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="WINDOWS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Windows is an operating system platform that many of the mentioned malware and tools, such as RegDuke and BlackEnergy, are designed to operate on.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="LINUX">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Linux is an operating system platform that supports various tools like Empire and Impacket.</data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <node id="MACOS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">macOS is an operating system platform that supports tools like Empire and Impacket.)<|COMPLETE|></data>      <data key="d2">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </node>    <edge source="REGDUKE" target="APT29">      <data key="d4">8.0</data>      <data key="d5">RegDuke is used by APT29 as a first stage implant to control compromised machines</data>      <data key="d6">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </edge>    <edge source="EMPIRE" target="GITHUB">      <data key="d4">7.0</data>      <data key="d5">Empire is publicly available on GitHub as an open source framework</data>      <data key="d6">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CARBON" target="TURLA">      <data key="d4">8.0</data>      <data key="d5">Carbon is selectively used by Turla to target government and foreign affairs-related organizations</data>      <data key="d6">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </edge>    <edge source="APPLESEED" target="KIMSUKY">      <data key="d4">8.0</data>      <data key="d5">AppleSeed is a backdoor used by Kimsuky to target South Korean entities</data>      <data key="d6">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BLACKENERGY" target="GEORGIA">      <data key="d4">9.0</data>      <data key="d5">BlackEnergy is known for its use during the confrontation between Georgia and Russia in 2008</data>      <data key="d6">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </edge>    <edge source="DOGCALL" target="APT37">      <data key="d4">8.0</data>      <data key="d5">DOGCALL is a backdoor used by APT37 to target South Korean government and military organizations</data>      <data key="d6">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </edge>    <edge source="TINY TURLA" target="TURLA">      <data key="d4">8.0</data>      <data key="d5">TinyTurla is a backdoor used by Turla against various international targets</data>      <data key="d6">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </edge>    <edge source="FINFISHER" target="GOVERNMENT AGENCIES">      <data key="d4">9.0</data>      <data key="d5">FinFisher is sold exclusively to government agencies for targeted investigations</data>      <data key="d6">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </edge>    <edge source="REVENGE RAT" target="OPEN SOURCE">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">Revenge RAT is a freely available tool, indicating its open source nature</data>      <data key="d6">572622effd5ff80ed4dace82977f612b</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
isher March 2018)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: Revenge RAT
Software description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ramsay
Software description: [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) is an information stealing malware framework designed to collect and exfiltrate sensitive documents, including from air-gapped systems. Researchers have identified overlaps between [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) and the [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012)-associated Retro malware.(Citation: Eset Ramsay May 2020)(Citation: Antiy CERT Ramsay April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DarkWatchman
Software description: [DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021.(Citation: Prevailion DarkWatchman 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: jRAT
Software description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012. Variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) have been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform, similar to an online subscription model.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016) (Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Kazuar
Software description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) is a fully featured, multi-platform backdoor Trojan written using the Microsoft .NET framework. (Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

Software name: Dyre
Software description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) is a banking Trojan that has been used for financial gain. 
 (Citation: Symantec Dyre June 2015)(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BISCUIT
Software description: [BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) is a backdoor that has been used by [APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) since as early as 2007. (Citation: Mandiant APT1)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RainyDay
Software description: [RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) is a backdoor tool that has been used by [Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) since at least 2020.(Citation: Bitdefender Naikon April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KONNI
Software description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) is a remote access tool that security researchers assess has been used by North Korean cyber actors since at least 2014. [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has significant code overlap with the [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) malware family, and has been linked to several suspected North Korean campaigns targeting political organizations in Russia, East Asia, Europe and the Middle East; there is some evidence potentially linking [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) to [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067).(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 Nokki Oct 2018)(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)(Citation: Malwarebytes Konni Aug 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bazar
Software description: [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) is a downloader and backdoor that has been used since at least April 2020, with infections primarily against professional services, healthcare, manufacturing, IT, logistics and travel companies across the US and Europe. [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) reportedly has ties to [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) campaigns and can be used to deploy additional malware, including ransomware, and to steal sensitive data.(Citation: Cybereason Bazar July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TinyZBot
Software description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004)

entities.name: RAINYDAY

chunk:
Europe. [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) reportedly has ties to [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) campaigns and can be used to deploy additional malware, including ransomware, and to steal sensitive data.(Citation: Cybereason Bazar July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TinyZBot
Software description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) is a bot written in C# that was developed by [Cleaver](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0003). (Citation: Cylance Cleaver)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PITSTOP
Software description: [PITSTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1123) is a backdoor that was deployed on compromised Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs during [Cutting Edge](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0029) to enable command execution and file read/write.(Citation: Mandiant Cutting Edge Part 3 February 2024)
Platforms: Network

Software name: Carberp
Software description: [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) is a credential and information stealing malware that has been active since at least 2009. [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484)'s source code was leaked online in 2013, and subsequently used as the foundation for the [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) backdoor.(Citation: Trend Micro Carberp February 2014)(Citation: KasperskyCarbanak)(Citation: RSA Carbanak November 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: VERMIN
Software description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) is a remote access tool written in the Microsoft .NET framework. It is mostly composed of original code, but also has some open source code. (Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SocGholish
Software description: [SocGholish](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1124) is a JavaScript-based loader malware that has been used since at least 2017. It has been observed in use against multiple sectors globally for initial access, primarily through drive-by-downloads masquerading as software updates. SocGholish is operated by [Mustard Tempest](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1020) and its access has been sold to groups including [Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119) for downloading secondary RAT and ransomware payloads.(Citation: SentinelOne SocGholish Infrastructure November 2022)(Citation: SocGholish-update)(Citation: Red Canary SocGholish March 2024)(Citation: Secureworks Gold Prelude Profile) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ShadowPad
Software description: [ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) is a modular backdoor that was first identified in a supply chain compromise of the NetSarang software in mid-July 2017. The malware was originally thought to be exclusively used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096), but has since been observed to be used by various Chinese threat activity groups. (Citation: Recorded Future RedEcho Feb 2021)(Citation: Securelist ShadowPad Aug 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky ShadowPad Aug 2017) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Flame
Software description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) is a sophisticated toolkit that has been used to collect information since at least 2010, largely targeting Middle East countries. (Citation: Kaspersky Flame)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EvilBunny
Software description: [EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396) is a C++ malware sample observed since 2011 that was designed to be a execution platform for Lua scripts.(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny Dec 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Turian
Software description: [Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) is a backdoor that has been used by [BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) to target Ministries of Foreign Affairs, telecommunication companies, and charities in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. First reported in 2021, [Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) is likely related to Quarian, an older backdoor that was last observed being used in 2013 against diplomatic targets in Syria and the United States.(Citation: ESET BackdoorDiplomacy Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: WindTail
Software description: [WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) is a macOS surveillance implant used by [Windshift](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0112). [WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) shares code similarities with Hack Back aka KitM OSX.(Citation: SANS Windshift August 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail1 dec 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail2 jan 2019)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Crutch
Software description: [Crutch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0538) is a backdoor designed for document theft that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org

entities.name: BAZAR
entities.description: Bazar is a malware reportedly tied to TrickBot campaigns, capable of deploying additional malware and stealing sensitive data.

entities.name: TRICKBOT
entities.description: TrickBot is a malware that has been involved in various cybercrime activities, including the deployment of ransomware.

entities.name: TINYBOT
entities.description: TinyZBot is a bot developed by Cleaver, written in C# and used for malicious activities.

entities.name: CLEAVER
entities.description: Cleaver is a group that developed the TinyZBot malware.

entities.name: PITSTOP
entities.description: PITSTOP is a backdoor malware deployed on compromised Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs for command execution and file manipulation.

entities.name: CUTTING EDGE
entities.description: Cutting Edge is a campaign during which the PITSTOP backdoor was deployed.

entities.name: CARBERP
entities.description: Carberp is a credential and information stealing malware that has been active since at least 2009, with its source code leaked in 2013.

entities.name: CARBANAK
entities.description: Carbanak is a backdoor that was developed using the leaked source code of Carberp.

entities.name: VERMIN
entities.description: VERMIN is a remote access tool written in .NET, composed of original and open-source code.

entities.name: SOCGHOLISH
entities.description: SocGholish is a JavaScript-based loader malware used for initial access through drive-by-downloads.

entities.name: MUSTARD TEMPEST
entities.description: Mustard Tempest is a group that operates SocGholish and sells its access to other groups.

entities.name: INDRIK SPIDER
entities.description: Indrik Spider is a group that has purchased access to SocGholish for deploying secondary malware.

entities.name: SHADOWPAD
entities.description: ShadowPad is a modular backdoor first identified in a supply chain compromise, used by various Chinese threat groups.

entities.name: FLAME
entities.description: Flame is a sophisticated toolkit used for information collection, primarily targeting Middle Eastern countries.

entities.name: EVILBUNNY
entities.description: EvilBunny is a C++ malware sample designed to execute Lua scripts.

entities.name: TURIAN
entities.description: Turian is a backdoor used by BackdoorDiplomacy to target various sectors in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia.

entities.name: BACKDOORDIPLOMACY
entities.description:
BackdoorDiplomacy is a group known for using various backdoors, including Turian, to target specific sectors.
BackdoorDiplomacy is a group that utilizes the Turian backdoor for cyber operations.

entities.name: WINDTAIL
entities.description: WindTail is a macOS surveillance implant used by Windshift, sharing code similarities with other malware.

entities.name: WINDSHIFT
entities.description: Windshift is a group that operates the WindTail surveillance implant.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description:
Windows is a platform on which various malware, including Bazar, TinyZBot, and others, are designed to operate.
Windows is the primary platform for various malware, including Carberp and Flame, indicating its relevance in cyber threats.)<|COMPLETE|>

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is a platform on which WindTail operates as a surveillance implant.

entities.name: NETWORK
entities.description: Network is a platform where PITSTOP operates as a backdoor for command execution and file manipulation.

entities.name: C#
entities.description: C# is the programming language used to develop TinyZBot, indicating its technical foundation.

entities.name: JAVASCRIPT
entities.description: JavaScript is the programming language used to create SocGholish, highlighting its technical aspect.

entities.name: C++
entities.description: C++ is the programming language used for EvilBunny, indicating its technical foundation.

entities.name: NET
entities.description: NET is the framework used to develop VERMIN, indicating its technical environment.

chunk:
with Hack Back aka KitM OSX.(Citation: SANS Windshift August 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail1 dec 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail2 jan 2019)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Crutch
Software description: [Crutch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0538) is a backdoor designed for document theft that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2015.(Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Gazer
Software description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) is a backdoor used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2016. (Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KeyBoy
Software description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) is malware that has been used in targeted campaigns against members of the Tibetan Parliament in 2016.(Citation: CitizenLab KeyBoy Nov 2016)(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CHOPSTICK
Software description: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) is a malware family of modular backdoors used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It has been used since at least 2012 and is usually dropped on victims as second-stage malware, though it has been used as first-stage malware in several cases. It has both Windows and Linux variants. (Citation: FireEye APT28) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017) (Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018) It is tracked separately from the [X-Agent for Android](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0314).
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: HotCroissant
Software description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed by U.S. government entities to malicious North Korean government cyber activity, tracked collectively as HIDDEN COBRA.(Citation: US-CERT HOTCROISSANT February 2020) [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) shares numerous code similarities with [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433).(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Catchamas
Software description: [Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) is a Windows Trojan that steals information from compromised systems. (Citation: Symantec Catchamas April 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Zeus Panda
Software description: [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) is a Trojan designed to steal banking information and other sensitive credentials for exfiltration. [Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330)’s original source code was leaked in 2011, allowing threat actors to use its source code as a basis for new malware variants. It is mainly used to target Windows operating systems ranging from Windows XP through Windows 10.(Citation: Talos Zeus Panda Nov 2017)(Citation: GDATA Zeus Panda June 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Emotet
Software description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) is a modular malware variant which is primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants such as [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) and [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483). Emotet first emerged in June 2014 and has been primarily used to target the banking sector. (Citation: Trend Micro Banking Malware Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SUGARDUMP
Software description: [SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042) is a proprietary browser credential harvesting tool that was used by UNC3890 during the [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010) campaign. The first known [SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042) version was used since at least early 2021, a second SMTP C2 version was used from late 2021-early 2022, and a third HTTP C2 variant was used since at least April 2022.(Citation: Mandiant UNC3890 Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Power Loader
Software description: [Power Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0177) is modular code sold in the cybercrime market used as a downloader in malware families such as Carberp, Redyms and Gapz. (Citation: MalwareTech Power Loader Aug 2013) (Citation: WeLiveSecurity Gapz and Redyms Mar 2013)
Platforms: None

Software name: WarzoneRAT
Software description: [WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670) is a malware-as-a-service remote access tool (RAT) written in C++ that has been publicly available for purchase since at least late 2018.(Citation: Check Point Warzone Feb 2020)(Citation: Uptycs Warzone UAC Bypass November 2020

entities.name: HACK BACK
entities.description: Hack Back, also known as KitM OSX, is associated with cyber activities and software development in the cybersecurity domain.

entities.name: TURNA
entities.description: Turla is a cyber espionage group known for its sophisticated malware and cyber attack strategies, particularly targeting government and military organizations.

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28 is a Russian cyber espionage group that has been involved in various high-profile cyber attacks and is known for its use of malware like CHOPSTICK.

entities.name: SUGARDUMP
entities.description: SUGARDUMP is a proprietary browser credential harvesting tool used by UNC3890 during specific cyber campaigns.

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a modular malware variant primarily used as a downloader for other malware, targeting the banking sector since 2014.

entities.name: CRUTCH
entities.description: Crutch is a backdoor designed for document theft, utilized by the Turla group since at least 2015.

entities.name: GAZER
entities.description: Gazer is a backdoor used by Turla since at least 2016, known for its stealthy operations.

entities.name: KEYBOY
entities.description: KeyBoy is malware that has been used in targeted campaigns against members of the Tibetan Parliament in 2016.

entities.name: CHOPSTICK
entities.description: CHOPSTICK is a malware family of modular backdoors used by APT28, known for its versatility and deployment in various cyber attacks.

entities.name: HOTCROISSANT
entities.description: HotCroissant is a remote access trojan attributed to North Korean government cyber activity, sharing similarities with other malware.

entities.name: CATCHAMAS
entities.description: Catchamas is a Windows Trojan that steals information from compromised systems.

entities.name: ZEUS PANDA
entities.description: Zeus Panda is a Trojan designed to steal banking information, with its source code leaked in 2011, leading to various malware variants.

entities.name: POWER LOADER
entities.description: Power Loader is modular code sold in the cybercrime market, used as a downloader in various malware families.

entities.name: WARZONERAT
entities.description: WarzoneRAT is a malware-as-a-service remote access tool available for purchase since at least late 2018.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that many of the mentioned malware and software are designed to operate on.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that Hack Back (KitM OSX) is associated with.

Platforms: None

Software name: WarzoneRAT
Software description: [WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670) is a malware-as-a-service remote access tool (RAT) written in C++ that has been publicly available for purchase since at least late 2018.(Citation: Check Point Warzone Feb 2020)(Citation: Uptycs Warzone UAC Bypass November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: njRAT
Software description: [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first observed in 2012. It has been used by threat actors in the Middle East.(Citation: Fidelis njRAT June 2013)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RCSession
Software description: [RCSession](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0662) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been in use since at least 2018 by [Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) and by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) (Type II Backdoor).(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE PRESIDENT December 2019)(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)(Citation: Trend Micro DRBControl February 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Calisto
Software description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is a macOS Trojan that opens a backdoor on the compromised machine. [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is believed to have first been developed in 2016. (Citation: Securelist Calisto July 2018) (Citation: Symantec Calisto July 2018)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Azorult
Software description: [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) is a commercial Trojan that is used to steal information from compromised hosts. [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) has been observed in the wild as early as 2016.
In July 2018, [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) was seen used in a spearphishing campaign against targets in North America. [Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) has been seen used for cryptocurrency theft. (Citation: Unit42 Azorult Nov 2018)(Citation: Proofpoint Azorult July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Zebrocy
Software description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) is a Trojan that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) since at least November 2015. The malware comes in several programming language variants, including C++, Delphi, AutoIt, C#, VB.NET, and Golang. (Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)(Citation: CISA Zebrocy Oct 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BabyShark
Software description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) is a Microsoft Visual Basic (VB) script-based malware family that is believed to be associated with several North Korean campaigns. (Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Duqu
Software description: [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) is a malware platform that uses a modular approach to extend functionality after deployment within a target network. (Citation: Symantec W32.Duqu)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DustySky
Software description: [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) is multi-stage malware written in .NET that has been used by [Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) since May 2015. (Citation: DustySky) (Citation: DustySky2)(Citation: Kaspersky MoleRATs April 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RATANKBA
Software description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) is a remote controller tool used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) has been used in attacks targeting financial institutions in Poland, Mexico, Uruguay, the United Kingdom, and Chile. It was also seen used against organizations related to telecommunications, management consulting, information technology, insurance, aviation, and education. [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) has a graphical user interface to allow the attacker to issue jobs to perform on the infected machines. (Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA) (Citation: RATANKBA)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cadelspy
Software description: [Cadelspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0454) is a backdoor that has been used by [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087).(Citation: Symantec Chafer Dec 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RemoteCMD
Software description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) is a

Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cadelspy
Software description: [Cadelspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0454) is a backdoor that has been used by [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087).(Citation: Symantec Chafer Dec 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RemoteCMD
Software description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) is a custom tool used by [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) to execute commands on a remote system similar to SysInternal's PSEXEC functionality. (Citation: Symantec Buckeye)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EvilGrab
Software description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) is a malware family with common reconnaissance capabilities. It has been deployed by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) via malicious Microsoft Office documents as part of spearphishing campaigns. (Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: schtasks
Software description: [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) is used to schedule execution of programs or scripts on a Windows system to run at a specific date and time. (Citation: TechNet Schtasks)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ISMInjector
Software description: [ISMInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0189) is a Trojan used to install another [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) backdoor, ISMAgent. (Citation: OilRig New Delivery Oct 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: StoneDrill
Software description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) is wiper malware discovered in destructive campaigns against both Middle Eastern and European targets in association with [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064).(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ZxShell
Software description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) is a remote administration tool and backdoor that can be downloaded from the Internet, particularly from Chinese hacker websites. It has been used since at least 2004.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ccf32
Software description: [ccf32](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1043) is data collection malware that has been used since at least February 2019, most notably during the [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0007) campaign; there is also a similar x64 version.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Proton
Software description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) is a macOS backdoor focusing on data theft and credential access  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mosquito
Software description: [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) is a Win32 backdoor that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). [Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) is made up of three parts: the installer, the launcher, and the backdoor. The main backdoor is called CommanderDLL and is launched by the loader program. (Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LookBack
Software description: [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582) is a remote access trojan written in C++ that was used against at least three US utility companies in July 2019. The TALONITE activity group has been observed using [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582).(Citation: Proofpoint LookBack Malware Aug 2019)(Citation: Dragos TALONITE)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Gelsemium
Software description: [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) is a modular malware comprised of a dropper (Gelsemine), a loader (Gelsenicine), and main (Gelsevirine) plug-ins written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC) framework. [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) has been used by the Gelsemium group since at least 2014.(Citation: ESET Gelsemium June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DanBot
Software description: [DanBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S

entities.name: MENUPASS

menuPass is a cyber threat group that deploys EvilGrab malware through spearphishing campaigns.
menuPass is a cyber threat group that deploys EvilGrab malware via malicious documents.

entities.name: ISMINJECTOR

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description:
OilRig is a cyber threat group that uses ISMInjector to deploy its backdoor.
OilRig is a cyber threat group that uses ISMInjector to install its backdoor, ISMAgent.

entities.name: STONEDRILL
entities.description: StoneDrill is wiper malware associated with APT33, targeting Middle Eastern and European entities.

entities.name: APT33
entities.description:
APT33 is a cyber threat group known for deploying StoneDrill malware.
APT33 is a cyber threat group known for deploying StoneDrill malware in destructive campaigns.

entities.name: ZXSHELL
entities.description: ZxShell is a remote administration tool and backdoor used by APT41.

entities.name: APT41
entities.description:
APT41 is a cyber threat group that utilizes ZxShell for remote administration.
APT41 is a cyber threat group that utilizes ZxShell for remote administration and backdoor access.

entities.name: CCF32
entities.description: ccf32 is data collection malware used in the FunnyDream campaign.

entities.name: FUNNYDREAM
entities.description:
FunnyDream is a cyber campaign during which ccf32 malware was notably used.
FunnyDream is a cyber campaign during which ccf32 malware was deployed.

entities.name: PROTON
entities.description: Proton is a macOS backdoor focusing on data theft and credential access.

entities.name: SILENTTRINITY
entities.description: SILENTTRINITY is an open-source remote administration framework used in cyber campaigns.

entities.name: MOSQUITO
entities.description: Mosquito is a Win32 backdoor used by Turla, consisting of multiple components.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a cyber threat group that employs Mosquito backdoor software.

entities.name: LOOKBACK
entities.description: LookBack is a remote access trojan used against US utility companies.

entities.name: GELSEMIUM
entities.description: Gelsemium is modular malware used by the Gelsemium group since at least 2014.

entities.name: GELSEMIUM GROUP
entities.description:
The Gelsemium group is a cyber threat actor known for using Gelsemium malware.
The Gelsemium group is a cyber threat actor known for using Gelsemium malware in their operations.)<|COMPLETE|>

entities.name: TALONITE
entities.description: TALONITE is an activity group that has been observed using LookBack malware against US utility companies.
